author: HCAndersen
text: VERY often, after a violent thunder-storm, a field of buckwheat appears blackened and singed, as if a flame of fire had passed over it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The country people say that this appearance is caused by lightning; but I will tell you what the sparrow says, and the sparrow heard it from an old willow-tree which grew near a field of buckwheat, and is there still.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is a large venerable tree, though a little crippled by age.

author: HCAndersen
text: The trunk has been split, and out of the crevice grass and brambles grow.

author: HCAndersen
text: The tree bends for-ward slightly, and the branches hang quite down to the ground just like green hair.

author: HCAndersen
text: Corn grows in the surrounding fields, not only rye and barley, but oats,-pretty oats that, when ripe, look like a number of little golden canary-birds sitting on a bough.

author: HCAndersen
text: The corn has a smiling look and the heaviest and richest ears bend their heads low as if in pious humility.

author: HCAndersen
text: Once there was also a field of buckwheat, and this field was exactly opposite to old willow-tree.

author: HCAndersen
text: The buckwheat did not bend like the other grain, but erected its head proudly and stiffly on the stem.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am as valuable as any other corn," said he, "and I am much handsomer; my flowers are as beautiful as the bloom of the apple blossom, and it is a pleasure to look at us.

author: HCAndersen
text: Do you know of anything prettier than we are, you old willow-tree?"

author: HCAndersen
text: And the willow-tree nodded his head, as if he would say, "Indeed I do."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the buckwheat spread itself out with pride, and said, "Stupid tree; he is so old that grass grows out of his body."

author: HCAndersen
text: There arose a very terrible storm.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the field-flowers folded their leaves together, or bowed their little heads, while the storm passed over them, but the buckwheat stood erect in its pride.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Bend your head as we do," said the flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have no occasion to do so," replied the buckwheat.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Bend your head as we do," cried the ears of corn; "the angel of the storm is coming; his wings spread from the sky above to the earth beneath.

author: HCAndersen
text: He will strike you down before you can cry for mercy."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But I will not bend my head," said the buckwheat.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Close your flowers and bend your leaves," said the old willow-tree.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do not look at the lightning when the cloud bursts; even men cannot do that.

author: HCAndersen
text: In a flash of lightning heaven opens, and we can look in; but the sight will strike even human beings blind.

author: HCAndersen
text: What then must happen to us, who only grow out of the earth, and are so inferior to them, if we venture to do so?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Inferior, indeed!" said the buckwheat.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I intend to have a peep into heaven."

author: HCAndersen
text: Proudly and boldly he looked up, while the lightning flashed across the sky as if the whole world were in flames.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the dreadful storm had passed, the flowers and the corn raised their drooping heads in the pure still air, refreshed by the rain, but the buckwheat lay like a weed in the field, burnt to blackness by the lightning.

author: HCAndersen
text: The branches of the old willow-tree rustled in the wind, and large water-drops fell from his green leaves as if the old willow were weeping.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the sparrows asked why he was weeping, when all around him seemed so cheerful.

author: HCAndersen
text: "See," they said, how the sun shines, and the clouds float in the blue sky.

author: HCAndersen
text: Do you not smell the sweet perfume from flower and bush?

author: HCAndersen
text: Wherefore do you weep, old willow-tree?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the willow told them of the haughty pride of the buckwheat, and of the punishment which followed in consequence.

author: HCAndersen
text: This is the story told me by the sparrows one evening when I begged them to relate some tale to me.
